<<<api>>>: POI Apache
<<<code>>>: int columnSize = sheet.getRow(0).getLastCellNum();
<<<explanation>>>: To get the size or length of a specific column in an Excel file using POI Apache, you can first get the first row of the sheet using sheet.getRow(0), and then call getLastCellNum() method on the row to get the number of cells in that row, which represents the size or length of the column.

<<<api>>>: POI Apache
<<<code>>>: int columnSize = sheet.getRow(0).getLastCellNum();
<<<explanation>>>: To get the size or length of a specific column in POI Apache, you can use the getLastCellNum() method on the row object. This method returns the index of the last cell in the row plus one, which represents the number of cells in that row. In this case, you can use the first row (index 0) to get the size of the specific column you're interested in.

<<<api>>>: POI Apache
<<<code>>>: int columnSize = sheet.getRow(0).getLastCellNum();
<<<explanation>>>: To get the size or length of a specific column in an Excel file using POI Apache, you can use the getLastCellNum() method on the row object. This method returns the index of the last cell contained in the row, which can be used as the column size. In the code snippet above, sheet.getRow(0) retrieves the first row (assuming it contains the column headers), and getLastCellNum() returns the size of that row, which represents the number of columns in the Excel file.

<<<code>>>: int columnSize = sheet.getRow(0).getLastCellNum();

<<<api>>>: POI Apache
<<<code>>>: int columnSize = sheet.getRow(0).getLastCellNum();
<<<explanation>>>: You can get the size or length of a specific column in an Excel file using POI Apache by getting the last cell number of the row that contains the column. In this example, we assume that the column is in the first row (row index 0) of the sheet. The getLastCellNum() method returns the index of the last cell contained in that row, so by getting the last cell number, you can determine the size or length of the column.
